Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Models for Supply Chain Design and Logistics Management of Biofuels

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award is to build integrated supply chain design and management models for biofuels. These supply chain models will (1) consider the specific nature of biomass supply; (2) take an integrated view of production, transportation, and inventory; and (3) integrate strategic, tactical, and operational decisions. The goal is to improve the performance of this supply chain, and consequently increase the practicality of biofuels as a source of energy. In pursuit of this objective, the following two research areas will be investigated. (1) Supply chain design problems. Two-stage stochastic programming models will be developed that integrate location decisions with transportation and inventory management decisions. (2) Production and distribution problems. Multi-criteria optimization models will be developed that minimize supply chain related costs, and maximize the positive impact of biofuels to the environment.

This research will significantly advance the knowledge base needed to address supply chain design and management problems for biofuels. Other industries, such as the personal computer and retail industries are already taking advantage of sophisticated supply chain designs. This work will help build the infrastructure that is necessary to switch from using petroleum to using biofuels as a source of renewable and sustainable energy, since well-organized supply chains have the potential to decrease transportation, inventory and other related supply chain costs. This research has the potential to positively impact the society by creating substantial economic value for farmers and biorefineries. Another major contribution of this award will be its impact to the education of graduate and undergraduate students through participation in this research project, and through discussion of related case-studies that will be used in the classroom.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit 

The research funded by this award contributed in improving our understanding of the impacts of supply chain activities on the generation of bioenergy. Initially, the research team developed optimization models which capture the impact of biomass physical characteristics (such as, humidity level, ash content, density, etc.) and seasonal availability on distribution network design, and production and transportation planning. The objective of these models was to minimize the cost of delivering bioenergy by optimizing supply chain related decisions. Models are developed to optimize the supply chain performance of different types of biomass (such as, agricultural residues, forest products and residues, waste from waste-water-treatment facilities) and bioenergy (such as, biofuel, biodiesel and bio-power). The proposed are extensions of stochastic location-transportation, blending, and chance constraint optimization models. The scope of these models was later extended to consider the impact of biomass supply chain decisions on the environment and society. For example, the findings from a life cycle assessment study are used to develop functional relationships between biomass utilization and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, and number of jobs created. These functional relationships are incorporated into a non-linear optimization model which evaluates the trade-offs between costs, GHG emissions and jobs created. Novel solution approaches are developed to solve the proposed models which are often nonlinear and nonconvex.

The models developed by this research team are evaluated via a number of case studies which were mainly focused on Southeast USA. Some of the data sources used are the Knowledge Discovery Framework database, the US Billion Ton Study, the Jobs and Economic Development Impact model, etc.

The research funded by this award also contributed in improving our understanding of the costs and environmental impacts of biomass co-firing, and related governmental incentives. Co-firing is a viewed by experts as near-term solution to reduce GHG emissions in coal-fired power plants since viable and long-term solution alternatives still remain in early or mid-stages of development.  An initial mathematical model was developed by this research team to estimate the total supply chain costs. This model captures the loss in process efficiencies due to using biomass (instead of coal), the additional investments necessary to support co-firing, and savings due to Production Tax Credit (PTC) which is a flat rate per kWh of renewable energy generated. Numerical results indicated that co-firing is economical in regions rich in biomass. It was also found that large-sized plants are at an advantage due to the structure of the PTC. A follow-up study used a resource allocation models to compare the flat PTC rate to other alternatives, such as, a capacity-based and a (biomass-to-coal) ratio-base schemes. These schemes are developed in an effort to improve the fairness of the existing incentive system. Numerical analysis using data from the Southeast region of USA indicated that the capacity-based incentive maximizes renewable energy generation and the number of plants co-firing in the region; the ratio-based scheme balances profitability and renewable energy generation among plants; and the existing flat PTC maximizes plant profitability but resulted in the least amount of bio-power generated in the region.

Current efforts are focused on extending these models to support decision making in decentralized biomass supply chains. Game theoretic models have been developed which capture the competitiveness and the hierarchy of decisions in the supply chain.

Broader Impacts

Findings of this research are disseminated via a number of peer reviewed publications and presentations. This award sponsored the research of a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students. Three PhD dissertations and two MS theses contributed to this research program.  The students contributed meaningfully to this work and are co-authors of these publications. The students had the opportunity to present their work in professional conferences at the local, national and international levels. Three students had the opportunity to complete summer internships at the Idaho National Laboratory (INL). One of these students is currently a research scientist at INL. This research fostered collaborations between the PI and faculty members in other fields within and outside engineering. 

Research findings have been used to developed class materials that are delivered to students taking a course in Transportation and Logistics Engineering at Mississippi State (MSU) and Clemson Universities. The typical size of this class at Clemson is 70 students, of which 50 are undergraduate and 20 graduate Industrial Engineers. Similar presentations were made to students in other engineering disciplines in these institutions.

 The PI has been involved in a number of K-12 outreach activities at MSU and Clemson through programs such as I AM GIRL, IMAGE Summer Bridge Program, Foundations In Research Experience, etc. Via presentations and hands-on activities she introduced female and minority students to the field of Industrial Engineering.
